channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Leader Was Defeated Even Before He Was Ousted
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovych was not so much overthrown as cast adrift by his own allies, and Western officials were just as surprised by the meltdown as anyone else.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police set up water cannons to shoot at protesters in Kiev last February. But shortly after, a mass defection of the president’s allies quickly led to his downfall.

item.title: North Korea Criticizes U.S. Over New Sanctions
item.description: Pyongyang reiterated its denial of involvement in the hacking of Sony and said that Washington’s sanctions would only strengthen its resolve to pursue its “military-first” policy.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Myanmar Returns to What Sells: Heroin
item.description: Over the past decade, poppy cultivation and the opium it produces have flourished as poor farmers turn to the profitable crop.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Condition of British Ebola Patient Worsens
item.description: Doctors treating Pauline Cafferkey, a Scottish nurse who was found to have Ebola after returning from volunteer work in Sierra Leone, say that her condition has deteriorated to critical.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: News Analysis: The Next Battle for Ukraine
item.description: A new activist generation seeks a shift in the way society and the state interact.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: In Kiev, Ukrainians argued with police officers during a rally in front of Parliament.

item.title: World Briefing: Vietnam: Norwegian Cargo Ship Sinks
item.description: A Norwegian shipping company said that one if its cargo vessels had sunk off the coast of Vietnam and that only one of the 19 Filipino crew members was known to have survived.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Qaeda Suspect Facing Trial in New York Over Africa Embassy Bombings Dies
item.description: A suspected leader of Al Qaeda, Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, who was to be tried this month in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa, died in government custody after suffering from liver cancer.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Police Arrest Fugitive Terrorist
item.description: Christodoulos Xiros, 56, had been serving six life terms for his role in the terrorist group November 17, which killed 23 people from 1975 to 2000.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: 13 Egyptian Christians Abducted
item.description: Masked gunmen in central Libya kidnapped 13 Coptic Christians on Saturday after seven were abducted days earlier, a witness and a priest said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Tensions Mount as Israel Freezes Revenue Meant for Palestinians
item.description: It is the first of an expected series of punitive measures in response to a push by the Palestinians to prosecute Israeli officials for war crimes during the battle with militants in the Gaza Strip last summer.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: World Briefing: France: Migrants Injured in Calais Brawl
item.description: A fight among about 200 migrants trying to get to Britain from the northern French port city of Calais left seven people injured on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Nurse Infected With Ebola Is in Critical Condition, Hospital Says
item.description: The nurse, Pauline Cafferkey, the first person found to have Ebola on British soil, returned to Britain on Dec. 28 from Sierra Leone.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Stanislaw Baranczak, 68, Polish Underground Poet, Dies
item.description: Mr. Baranczak defied state censors to write about living under Communist oppression and later emigrated to the United States, where he taught at Harvard.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: Stanislaw Baranczak in Poland in 1991, years after the poet left the country to live and teach in the United States.

item.title: F.B.I. Employees With Ties Abroad See Security Bias
item.description: An F.B.I. program aimed at reducing internal threats is said to be penalizing employees hired for their foreign language skills by subjecting them to higher scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Gamal Abdel-Hafiz was hired in 1994 as an Arabic linguist.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China-Japan Dispute Over Islands Spreads to Cyberspace
item.description: In a new effort to bolster its claim to disputed islands in the East China Sea, the Chinese government has introduced a website under their Chinese name, Diaoyu. Japan already has a website detailing its sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: The disputed islands in the East China Sea are called the Diaoyu by China and the Senkaku by Japan. Conflicting claims over the islands have exacerbated tensions between the two countries.

item.title: Turkey’s President Traces a New Internal Threat: The Way He’s Drawn
item.description: Editorial cartoonists have long been a staple of Turkish politics, but President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is not amused, and is using the courts to crack down on them.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: A cartoon titled “political discourse” portrays President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey spraying tear gas.

item.title: Indian and Pakistani Guards Trade Fire on Disputed Border
item.description: The exchange of fire across the northern border in the state of Jammu and Kashmir left at least two people dead and at least one other wounded, officials said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: After Killing of Gaza Teenager, Calls for Egyptian Inquiry
item.description: Palestinian officials are demanding that the Egyptian government investigate the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old boy from Gaza who they say was killed by Egyptian soldiers.
item.dc:creator: By MAJD AL WAHEIDI and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Five Arrested in India Rape Case
item.description: A Japanese woman said that she had been lured to the Gaya district in Bihar by a man posing as a tour guide and raped, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: 4 Large Objects Detected in AirAsia Wreckage Hunt
item.description: Indonesian officials say they're confident wreckage of AirAsia Flight 8501 has been located after sonar equipment detected four massive objects on the ocean floor.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Members of the Indonesian Navy on Saturday with the bagged body of a passenger from AirAsia Flight 8501. Indonesian officials say that sonar equipment has detected four large objects on the floor of the Java Sea, and that they believe the objects are wreckage from the plane, which crashed a week ago. The remains of most of the 162 people who were on board are still missing.
